name: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)
etiology_pathogenesis:
Etiology & Pathogenesis

Definition: Pathological proliferation of glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma within the Transitional Zone (surrounding urethra). This compresses the peripheral zone into a 'False Capsule'. A 'Middle Lobe' may project into the bladder neck.
Hormonal Drivers: Testosterone is metabolized to Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha-reductase, stimulating proliferation. Aging leads to a relative increase in Oestrogenic effects vs Testosterone.
Epidemiology: Histological evidence in 50% of men >60 years.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features & Consequences

LUTS Categories:
- Voiding (Obstructive): Mechanical compression causes Poor stream, Hesitancy, Intermittency, Terminal Dribbling.
- Storage (Irritative): Secondary detrusor instability causes Frequency, Nocturia, Urgency.
Complications:
- Retention: Acute (Painful) or Chronic (Painless/Overflow).
- Upper Tract: High pressure causes Hydronephrosis → Renal Impairment/Uraemia.
- Local: UTIs, Bladder Stones, Hematuria (ruptured veins).
assessment:
Assessment & Investigation

Clinical: IPSS Score (Symptom severity), Frequency-Volume Chart.
DRE Findings: Smooth, convex, rubbery, and symmetrical. Median sulcus preserved. Rectal mucosa mobile. (Essential to exclude Ca).
Functional Tests:
- Uroflowmetry: Qmax <10 mL/s is low.
- Post-Void Residual (PVR): >250 mL associated with chronic retention.
- Pressure-Flow Studies: Definitive Test for BOO (High voiding pressure >80 cmH2O + Low flow).
Imaging: USS/CT to screen for hydronephrosis.
management:
Management & Treatment

1. Conservative: Watchful waiting for mild symptoms (IPSS 0–7) + Fluid restriction.
2. Medical:
- Alpha-Blockers (Tamsulosin): Relax smooth muscle (Rapid relief).
- 5-Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors (Finasteride): Shrink prostate volume (Takes 6–12 months). Best for glands >40g.
3. Surgical:
- TURP: Gold Standard. [Image of transurethral resection of prostate procedure] Monopolar/Bipolar resection. Risk of Retrograde Ejaculation (65–85%).
- HoLEP: Laser enucleation.
- Open Prostatectomy: For glands >75g.

name: Prostate Carcinoma
epidemiology_pathogenesis:
Epidemiology & Pathogenesis

Epidemiology: Most frequent malignancy in men. Predominantly affects age >65 (mean 70y). Incidence rises sharply after 50. 70% of men >80y have microscopic disease (die with it, not of it).
Hormonal Drivers: Growth stimulated by Testosterone. Testosterone → Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) (via enzyme 5-alpha-reductase) → Nuclear transcription → Proliferation.
Location: Originates in the Peripheral Zone.
pathology_spread:
Pathology, Grading & Spread

Histology: Adenocarcinoma.
Grading (Gleason): Score 2-10. Sum of two most common architectural patterns (e.g., 3+4=7). Higher score = Poorer prognosis. (ISUP Group 1 = Gleason 6).
Spread:
- Local: Seminal vesicles, Bladder neck, Trigone, Distal sphincter.
- Lymphatic: Obturator fossa, Internal/External Iliac nodes. Distant: Supraclavicular (Virchow's node).
- Bone (Haematogenous): Most common site (Pelvis/Lumbar spine). Lesions are Osteosclerotic/Osteoblastic (dense/hard).
clinical_diagnosis:
Clinical Presentation & Diagnosis

Symptoms: Early is asymptomatic. Later: LUTS (Hesitancy, Frequency) mimics BPH but more rapid. Advanced: Bone pain (night), Hydronephrosis.
DRE Findings: Irregular, stony hard, nodular, obliteration of median sulcus.
Investigations:
- PSA: >10ng/mL suggests Ca; >35ng/mL diagnostic (exclude UTI).
- mpMRI: Local staging (T-stage). Uses PI-RADS score.
- Biopsy: TRUS or Transperineal guidance.
- PSMA-PET: Highly sensitive for metastases.
TNM Staging: T1: Impalpable. T2: Confined to capsule. T3: Breaches capsule. T4: Fixed to structures.
management:
Management Modalities

Decisions via MDT based on stage/grade/age.
1. Curative (Localized):
- Radical Prostatectomy (RP): Removal of gland + seminal vesicles. Risks: ED, Incontinence.
- Radiotherapy: External Beam or Brachytherapy.
- Active Surveillance: For low-risk/indolent disease. Monitor PSA/Biopsy.
2. Palliative (Metastatic/T3-T4):
- Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT): Surgical Castration (Orchiectomy) or Medical (LHRH Agonists e.g., Goserelin).
- Chemotherapy: Docetaxel for hormone-refractory.
- Symptomatic: TURP (obstruction), Bisphosphonates (bone pain).

name: Carbuncle
etiology_pathogenesis:
Etiology & Pathogenesis

Definition: Deep, necrotizing infection of a cluster of contiguous hair follicles. More severe than a simple boil (furuncle).
Organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
Pathology: Deep suppuration creates a central core of necrotic tissue. Pus discharges via multiple sinuses (cribriform appearance). Subcutaneous spread > Skin redness.
Sites: Nape of neck, shoulders, back (thick skin areas).
Risk Factors: Diabetes (Mandatory to screen), Immunosuppression, General debility.
clinical_presentation:
Clinical Presentation

Symptoms: Throbbing pain (severe, keeps patient awake), Fever, Rigors, Malaise.
Signs:
- Initial: Red, hard, exquisitely tender nodule.
- Later: Central softening (fluctuation) with 'sieve-like' multiple openings discharging pus and necrotic slough.
- Systemic: Signs of toxaemia (Tachycardia, Pyrexia).
management:
Management

Investigation:
- Urine/Blood Glucose: Rule out Diabetes.
- Pus Swab: Culture & Sensitivity.
Treatment:
1. Surgery: Crucial. Incision & Drainage (Cruciate incision) to excise necrotic slough.
2. Antibiotics: IV/Oral Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., Flucloxacillin). Indicated because of systemic involvement (unlike simple boils).
3. Optimisation: Control blood sugar strictly.

name: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
definition_technique:
Definition & Technique

Definition: Combined endoscopic and fluoroscopic procedure. Primarily therapeutic, but relies on contrast imaging for real-time diagnosis.
Technique: Side-viewing duodenoscope cannulates the Ampulla of Vater. Radiopaque contrast is injected retrograde into biliary/pancreatic ducts.
Pre-requisite: Often preceded by non-invasive MRCP to map anatomy.
biliary_interpretation:
Biliary Interpretation

1. Choledocholithiasis: Stones appear as filling defects within the contrast-filled duct. (Rx: Sphincterotomy + Basket/Balloon extraction).
2. Strictures:
- Malignant: Abrupt cut-off or 'rat-tail' narrowing (Cholangiocarcinoma/Pancreatic Ca).
- Benign: Smooth tapering (Post-surgical/Chronic Pancreatitis).
- PSC: 'Beaded' appearance of irregular narrowing and dilation.
3. Cholangioscopy: Direct visual inspection (SpyGlass) for indeterminate strictures.
pancreatic_interpretation:
Pancreatic Interpretation

1. Double Duct Sign: Concurrent stricture of both distal CBD and Main Pancreatic Duct. Highly suggestive of Pancreatic Head Carcinoma.
2. Chronic Pancreatitis: 'Chain of lakes' appearance (dilatation + strictures) + Intraductal calcification.
3. Tissue Sampling: Brush cytology/Biopsy from strictures for histology.
post_procedure:
Procedural Outcomes

Clearance: Balloon sweep + cholangiogram confirms no residual filling defects (stones).
Stenting: Plastic or Metal (SEMS) stents placed across strictures. Success signs: Immediate bile flow ('gush') and later Pneumobilia (air in biliary tree) on plain X-ray.

name: Sengstaken-Blakemore Tube
definition_mechanism:
Definition & Mechanism

Definition: [Image of Sengstaken-Blakemore tube scheme] Specialized device for temporary control of acute, massive variceal haemorrhage (Oesophageal/Gastric) via Balloon Tamponade. Acts as a bridge to definitive therapy (TIPSS/Endoscopy).
Mechanism: Mechanical compression of bleeding vasculature at the Gastro-Oesophageal Junction (GOJ).
components:
Components

1. Gastric Balloon: Anchors tube and compresses subcardiac varices. Inflated with 200-300ml air (Check manufacturer).
2. Oesophageal Balloon: Cylindrical balloon compresses oesophageal varices. Pressure maintained at ~30-40 mmHg (Monitor carefully!).
3. Aspiration Channels: For gastric decompression. Minnesota Tube is a variant with a 4th lumen for oesophageal aspiration (preventing aspiration pneumonia).
management_safety:
Management & Safety

Airway: Intubation is recommended PRIOR to insertion to prevent pulmonary aspiration.
Insertion: Insert via mouth. Radiological confirmation of gastric balloon position is mandatory before full inflation.
Protocol:
- Traction applied to seat gastric balloon against GOJ.
- Deflate balloons every 12h to prevent Pressure Necrosis (mucosal ischaemia).
- Max duration: usually 24h.
complications:
Complications

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: High risk (hence intubate).
2. Oesophageal Perforation: From misplaced balloon inflation.
3. Pressure Necrosis/Ulceration: If left inflated too long or pressure too high.
4. Airway Obstruction: If tube migrates upwards.

name: Proctoscopy (Anoscopy)
definition_indications:
Definition & Indications

Definition: A short, illuminated tube used for direct visualization of the anal canal and lower rectum. Essential for evaluating anorectal symptoms.
Indications:
1. Hemorrhoids: Visualization of cushions (Left Lateral, Right Posterior, Right Anterior). Confirms diagnosis and mucosal prolapse.
2. Rectal Bleeding: Mandatory in all patients with bright red bleeding.
3. Pathology: Low rectal polyps, carcinomas, proctitis, or squamous metaplasia.
4. Fistula/Fissure: May identify internal fistula openings. Caution: Avoid if patient has a painful fissure (requires EUA).
technique:
Procedural Technique

Position: Left lateral (Sims) position with knees drawn to chest. No bowel prep usually required.
Insertion: Lubricate well. Insert with obturator in place, aiming towards umbilicus (axis of anal canal).
Visualization: Remove obturator. Withdraw instrument slowly while inspecting the mucosa.
Maneuver: Ask patient to strain during withdrawal. This causes internal hemorrhoids to distend and prolapse into the scope.
context_therapeutics:
Context & Comparison

Therapeutic Use: Allows access for Rubber Band Ligation (RBL) or Sclerotherapy injection of hemorrhoids.
vs Rigid Sigmoidoscopy: Proctoscope sees anal canal. Rigid sigmoidoscope (25-30cm) reaches the rectosigmoid junction.
Clinical Rule: Finding hemorrhoids on proctoscopy does NOT exclude proximal causes of bleeding (e.g., Cancer). Flexible Sigmoidoscopy or Colonoscopy is mandatory in older/high-risk patients to rule out higher pathology.

name: Chest Tube (Intercostal Drain)
indications:
Indications for Insertion

1. Pneumothorax: Air in pleural space (Spontaneous, Traumatic, or Secondary to COPD). Mandatory if patient is on mechanical ventilation.
2. Haemothorax: Blood accumulation. Massive Haemothorax: >1500ml immediate drainage or >200ml/hr for 3-4 hours (requires Thoracotomy).
3. Pleural Effusion/Empyema: Drainage of fluid or pus (fibrino-purulent stage).
4. Post-Surgical: After lobectomy/oesophagectomy to manage leaks.
technique_placement:
Technique & Placement


Triangle of Safety: Bordered by Pectoralis Major (Ant), Latissimus Dorsi (Post), and Nipple level (Sup).
Insertion: 4th-6th Intercostal Space. Incision is sharp, dissection is blunt.
Neurovascular Bundle: Pass drain OVER the superior border of the rib to avoid the bundle (Vein/Artery/Nerve) located under the rib.
Direction: Aim Apical for Air, Basal for Fluid.
management:
Management Principles

Underwater Seal: Acts as a one-way valve allowing exit but preventing re-entry of air/fluid.
Suction: Only if lung fails to expand. Risk of increasing air leak in fragile lungs.
Clamping: NEVER clamp a bubbling drain (risks Tension Pneumothorax).
Removal: When lung re-expanded/leak stops. Patient performs Valsalva Manoeuvre (breath in & hold) during removal to prevent air entry.
emergency_tension:
Tension Pneumothorax

Pathophysiology: Air accumulates under pressure -> Mediastinal shift -> CVS collapse. Clinical Diagnosis (Do not wait for X-ray).
Immediate Action: Needle Decompression (Large bore cannula in 2nd ICS Mid-clavicular line).
Definitive Action: Insert Chest Tube immediately after decompression.

name: Varicose Veins
definition_pathophysiology:
Definition & Pathophysiology

Definition: Tortuous, dilated, and prominent superficial veins of the lower limbs.
Pathophysiology: Venous hypertension caused by valvular failure leading to retrograde blood flow (reflux). This pressure damages soft tissues, defining the spectrum of Chronic Venous Insufficiency (CVI).
classification:
Classification

Primary: Most common. Inherited weakness of vein wall (loss of compliance) leading to secondary valve failure. Tributaries lack strong muscle coats, making them susceptible.
Secondary: Due to proximal obstruction or high pressure. Causes: DVT (Post-thrombotic syndrome), Pelvic mass, or Congenital (Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome).
risk_factors:
Risk Factors

Mechanical: Prolonged standing.
Demographics: Age, Female gender.
Hormonal: Pregnancy (Progesterone relaxes smooth muscle + Gravid uterus compresses IVC). OCP/HRT use.
Obesity: High BMI.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Symptoms: Aching, heaviness, throbbing, burning (worse end of day/standing, relieved by elevation).
Signs: Visible tortuous veins. Saphena Varix: Dilation at SFJ with cough impulse (mistaken for hernia).
Complications:
1. Superficial Thrombophlebitis (SVT): Red, painful, tender cord. Risk of DVT if near SFJ.
2. Skin Changes: Haemosiderin (brown), Eczema, Lipodermatosclerosis (champagne bottle leg).
3. Venous Ulcers: Shallow, irregular, medial malleolus (gaiter area).
4. Bleeding: High pressure rupture.
investigation:
Investigation

Duplex Ultrasound: Gold Standard. Non-invasive. Maps reflux (defined as retrograde flow ≥0.5s), checks deep vein patency, and locates incompetent perforators.
Special Tests: Trendelenburg Test (locates level of incompetence) and Perthes Test (deep vein patency) are largely historical.
management:
Management

Conservative: Compression hosiery (Class II), Elevation, Weight loss.
Interventional (Endovenous): First Line.
- Thermal Ablation: Radiofrequency (RFA) or Laser (EVLA). Burns/seals vein from inside.
- Sclerotherapy: Foam injection (e.g., Polidocanol) under USG guidance to fibrose vein.
Surgery:
- High Tie & Strip: Ligation of SFJ + Stripping of Long Saphenous Vein.
- Avulsions: Stab phlebectomy for tributaries.
Nerve Risks: Saphenous nerve (with LSV stripping), Sural nerve (with SSV surgery).

name: Urinary Catheterisation
indications_contraindications:
Indications & Contraindications

Indications:
1. Urinary Retention: Acute (painful) or Chronic (painless high residuals).
2. Monitoring: Hourly urine output in shock/sepsis (Target >0.5ml/kg/hr).
3. Irrigation: Hematuria (washout clots).
4. Surgical: Pelvic surgery or prolonged procedures.
Contraindications:
- Suspected Urethral Trauma: Blood at meatus, perineal bruising, or 'high-riding' prostate on PR. Risk: Converting partial tear to complete disruption. Action: Suprapubic Catheter (SPC) or retrograde urethrogram.
types_sizes:
Types & Sizing

Types:
- Foley: Standard indwelling (Latex or Silicone).
- Coudé tip: Curved tip for difficult insertion (BPH).
- 3-Way: For irrigation (Inlet, Outlet, Balloon). Used in TURP/Hematuria.
Sizes (French Gauge - Fr):
- 12-14 Fr: Standard adult (clear urine).
- 16-18 Fr: Turbid urine/debris.
- 20-24 Fr: Clot retention (stiff, wide bore).
procedure_complications:
Procedure & Complications

Key Steps: Sterile technique. Retract foreskin. Instill lignocaine gel (11ml) and wait 3 mins. Insert to hilt (bifurcation) before inflating balloon (prevents inflating in urethra). Always replace foreskin to prevent paraphimosis.
Complications:
- CAUTI: Catheter Associated UTI (Most common hospital acquired infection).
- Trauma: False passage (forcing against resistance).
- Paraphimosis: Swollen glans due to tight foreskin ring.
- Blockage: Encrustation or clots.
troubleshooting:
Troubleshooting 'No Urine'

1. Blocked (Post-renal): Palpate bladder. Flush catheter with 20ml saline. If it flows in but not out -> Valve effect/Kink. If it won't go in -> Blocked.
2. Hypovolemia (Pre-renal): Catheter patent but kidney not making urine. Look for tachycardia/hypotension.
3. Dislodged: Balloon in urethra? (Pain + bypassing).

name: Gangrene & Necrotizing Infections
definitions_types:
Definitions & Etiology

Definition: Death of macroscopic portions of tissue due to severe, uncorrected ischemia. The characteristic black color is caused by hemoglobin breakdown forming iron sulfide.
Etiology: Interruption of arterial blood flow (Thrombosis, Embolism, Arteritis) or small vessel disease (Diabetes, Buerger's). A limb requires amputation if it is "Dead, Deadly, or a Dead Loss".

Classification

1. Dry Gangrene: Gradual arterial obstruction (Atherosclerosis) with patent veins. Tissue becomes desiccated and mummifies. Features: Dry, shriveled, black, hard. A clear Line of Demarcation forms between living and dead tissue. Usually sterile/painless.
2. Wet (Infected) Gangrene: Tissue death compounded by infection and putrefaction. Features: Swollen, boggy, foul smell. Infection extends into living tissue causing an indistinct line of demarcation or distant "skip" areas. Severe toxaemia.
3. Diabetic Gangrene: Multifactorial etiology involving macrovascular disease, microvascular dysfunction, neuropathy, and immunosuppression.
gas_gangrene:
Gas Gangrene (Clostridial Myonecrosis)

Aetiology: Clostridium perfringens (Gram +ve anaerobic spores). Associated with deep, penetrating wounds contaminated with soil/faeces.
Pathophysiology: Exotoxins (Alpha-toxin) cause rapid muscle necrosis and systemic haemolysis.
Clinical Features:
- Local: Sudden onset severe pain (earliest symptom), Crepitus (gas in tissues), and thin, brownish, 'sickly sweet' rotting apple exudate.
- Systemic: Profound toxaemia (Fever, Rigors, Tachycardia, Shock).
X-ray: Feathered pattern of gas in muscle planes.
necrotizing_fasciitis:
Necrotizing Fasciitis

Highly lethal 'Synergistic Gangrene' spreading rapidly along fascial planes, causing vascular thrombosis and necrosis of subcutaneous tissue/fascia.
Types:
- Polymicrobial: Mixed flora. Includes Fournier's Gangrene (Perineum/Scrotum).
- Monomicrobial: Group A Beta-haemolytic Streptococcus ('Flesh-eating bacteria').
Clinical Signs: Pain out of proportion to physical appearance, hemorrhagic bullae, skin anaesthesia (nerve death), 'Dishwater' pus.
Finger Test: Finger passes easily through subcutaneous tissue due to fascial liquefaction.
management:
Management Principles

1. Resuscitation & Antibiotics: Aggressive IV fluids (Septic shock) and Blood transfusion (Haemolysis). Broad-spectrum antibiotics are mandatory.
- Specifics: Penicillin (drug of choice for Clostridial/Strep) + Clindamycin (inhibits toxin production).
2. Radical Debridement: Primary Treatment. Urgent excision of ALL necrotic tissue until healthy bleeding muscle is seen. 'Time is tissue'. Re-look surgery in 24-48h.
3. Amputation: Indicated if limb is non-functional, infection is life-threatening (Gas gangrene), or ischemia is irreversible.
4. Vascular Intervention: Angioplasty/Bypass may be needed to improve proximal flow for successful amputation healing.
5. Adjuncts: Hyperbaric Oxygen (inhibits anaerobes/reduces debridement extent).

name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
pre_op_assessment:
1. Pre-operative Assessment

  • History (AMPPLE): Allergies, Medications, Past history, Pregnancy/Last meal, Events.
    Functional Status: Measured in METs (Metabolic Equivalents).
    - >4 METs: Can climb 1 flight of stairs (Low risk).
    - <4 METs: Cannot climb stairs (High cardiac risk).
  • ASA Grading:
    - I: Healthy.
    - II: Mild systemic disease (Smoker, Pregnant, Well-controlled HTN).
    - III: Severe systemic disease (COPD, Angina, Prior MI).
    - IV: Threat to life (Sepsis, Renal failure).
    - V: Moribund (Ruptured AAA).
  • Airway (Mallampati): Class I (Soft palate/uvula visible) to Class IV (Hard palate only). Predicts difficult intubation.
medication_bridge:
2. Drug Management

  • Stop:
    - Warfarin: Stop 5 days pre-op. Bridge with LMWH if high risk (metal valve). Check INR <1.5.
    - Clopidogrel: Stop 7 days pre-op (unless cardiac stent <12mo).
    - ACEi/ARBs: Omit morning dose (prevents refractory hypotension).
    - Oral Hypoglycemics: Omit morning dose. Metformin held if contrast used.
    - COCP/HRT: Stop 4 weeks pre-major surgery (VTE risk).
  • Continue: Beta-blockers, Statins, Antiepileptics, Thyroxine, Steroids (Need IV Hydrocortisone 'Stress Dose' if on long-term steroids to prevent Addisonian crisis).
pre_op_prep:
3. Patient Preparation

  • Fasting (2-4-6 Rule): 2h Clear fluids, 4h Breast milk, 6h Solids. Minimizes aspiration (Mendelson's Syndrome).
  • VTE Prophylaxis:
    - Mechanical: TED stockings, Pneumatic compression.
    - Chemical: LMWH (Enoxaparin) 6-12h pre-op. Caprini Score assesses risk.
  • Antibiotics: Single dose at induction (<60 mins before incision).
    - Clean-Contaminated: Cefuroxime + Metronidazole (GI surgery).
    - Implant: Flucloxacillin/Gentamicin (Ortho).
post_op_care:
4. Post-Op Management

  • Immediate (Recovery): ABCDE. Check Airway patency, SpO2 >94%, BP/HR (Hemorrhage?), Urine >0.5ml/kg/hr. Temp (Hypothermia causes coagulopathy).
  • Fluid Balance:
    - Maintenance: 25-30ml/kg/day H2O + 1mmol/kg Na/K.
    - Losses: Replace NGT/Drain losses mL-for-mL with Hartmann's.
  • ERAS (Enhanced Recovery): Early mobilization, Early enteral feeding, Opioid sparing analgesia, Removal of catheters/drains <24h.
complications:
The 5 W's of Post-Op Fever

  • Day 1-2 (Wind): Atelectasis (collapsed alveoli due to pain/splinting). Most common. Rx: Physio/Analgesia.
  • Day 3-5 (Water): UTI (Catheter associated). Rx: Remove catheter.
  • Day 5-7 (Wound): SSI. Rx: Open sutures, drain pus. Anastomotic Leak (Tachycardia + Pain).
  • Day 7+ (Walk): DVT / PE. Rx: Anticoagulation.
  • Anytime (Wonder Drugs): Drug fever, Transfusion reaction, Cannula site phlebitis.

name: Wound Healing & Types
clinical_types:
Common Surgical Wounds

  • Incisional: Clean, linear edges (Scalpel). Heals by Primary Intention. Complication: Dehiscence (separation of layers).
  • Laceration: Blunt trauma tearing tissue. Irregular edges, high contamination risk. Requires debridement.
  • Abrasion: Superficial epidermis removal (Road rash). Heals by epithelialization (no scar if dermis intact).
  • Degloving: Skin/subcutis stripped from fascia. Devitalizes skin flaps. Requires grafting.
  • Pressure Ulcers (Decubitus): Ischemia over bony prominences.
    - Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema.
    - Stage 2: Partial thickness (blister).
    - Stage 3: Full thickness skin loss (fat visible).
    - Stage 4: Exposed bone/tendon/muscle.
  • Necrotizing Fasciitis: Life-threatening infection of deep fascia. 'Dishwater' pus, crepitus, pain out of proportion. Surgical Emergency (Debridement).
physiology:
Phases of Healing

  1. Hemostasis (Mins): Vasoconstriction, Platelet plug, Fibrin clot (scaffold).
  2. Inflammation (Days 1-4): Neutrophils (kill bacteria) -> Macrophages (The 'Conductor' - debride and secrete growth factors). Signs: Rubor, Calor, Tumor, Dolor.
  3. Proliferation (Days 4-21):
    - Fibroblasts: Collagen III (weak).
    - Angiogenesis: New vessels.
    - Granulation: Beefy red matrix.
    - Epithelialization: Migration from edges.
  4. Remodeling (3 weeks - 1 year): Collagen III replaced by strong Type I. Cross-linking. Scar contracts. Max strength 80% of original.
classification:
Types of Union

Primary Intention: Clean edges approximated (Sutures/Staples). Minimal scar.
Secondary Intention: Wound left open (Abscess/Trauma). Heals from bottom up by granulation/contraction. Slow, wide scar.
Tertiary Intention: Delayed primary. Left open 3-5 days (allow infection to clear), then sutured.
factors:
Factors Affecting Healing

Systemic: Age, Malnutrition (Albumin <30, Vit C/Zinc def), Diabetes (microangiopathy), Steroids (inhibit macrophages), Smoking (Hypoxia), Jaundice, Uremia.
Local: Infection (Commonest), Ischemia (Tension/Hypotension), Foreign Body, Hematoma, Radiation.

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
definition_features:
Definitions

Keloid: An overgrowth of dense fibrous tissue (Type I & III collagen) that extends BEYOND the boundaries of the original wound. It does not regress spontaneously.
Hypertrophic Scar: Excessive scar tissue that remains confined WITHIN the boundaries of the original wound. It often regresses with time (6-12 months).
epidemiology_risk:
Risk Factors

Keloid:
- Race: Darker skin types (African/Asian).
- Genetics: Familial predisposition.
- Sites: Sternum, Deltoid, Earlobes, Upper Back (High tension areas rare).
Hypertrophic:
- Tension: Wounds closed under tension or crossing Langer's lines.
- Infection: Delayed healing.
- Burns: Deep dermal burns.
pathology_comparison:
Pathology Differences

FeatureKeloidHypertrophic
ExtentInvades normal skinConfined to wound
RegressionRareCommon
OnsetDelayed (>3 months)Early (<4 weeks)
CollagenThick, disorganized bundlesFine, organized parallel fibers
RecurrenceHigh (>50% post-excision)Low
management_treatment:
Management

Prevention: Minimize tension, avoid mid-sternal incisions in high-risk patients.
Keloid Treatment:
1. Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone): First line. Softens and flattens.
2. Pressure Garments: Continuous pressure (e.g., ear clips).
3. Silicone Gel Sheets.
4. Surgery: NEVER excise alone (recurrence is larger). Must combine with post-op Radiotherapy or Steroids.
Hypertrophic Treatment: Massage, Silicone, Time (wait 1 year before revision).

name: CDC Wound Classification
class_i_ii:
Clean & Clean-Contaminated

  • Class I (Clean): Uninfected operative wound. No inflammation. Respiratory, GI, Genitourinary tracts NOT entered. Primary closure. Infection risk: <2%. (e.g., Hernia repair, Mastectomy, Thyroidectomy).
  • Class II (Clean-Contaminated): Viscus (GI/Resp/GU) entered under controlled conditions. No unusual spillage. Infection risk: <10%. (e.g., Elective Cholecystectomy, Elective Colectomy). Prophylactic antibiotics indicated.
class_iii_iv:
Contaminated & Dirty

  • Class III (Contaminated): Open, fresh, accidental wounds. Major break in sterile technique. Gross spillage from GI tract. Acute non-purulent inflammation. Infection risk: 15-20%. (e.g., Stab wound, Bile spillage during chole).
  • Class IV (Dirty/Infected): Old traumatic wounds (>4h), devitalized tissue, existing clinical infection (pus) or perforated viscera. Infection risk: >40%. (e.g., Perforated diverticulitis, Abscess drainage). Therapeutic antibiotics required.
management_implications:
Surgical Implications

Closure Strategy:
- Class I/II: Primary Closure (Suture/Staple).
- Class III: Delayed Primary Closure (Tertiary Intention) - leave skin open, pack, close day 3-5.
- Class IV: Leave Open (Secondary Intention) to drain pus.
SSI Risk Reduction:
- Pre-op showering.
- Hair clipping (not shaving).
- Normothermia.
- Glucose control.

name: Routine Biochemical Tests
hematology:
Full Blood Count (FBC)

  • Hemoglobin (Hb):
    - Microcytic: Iron deficiency (Look for GI Ca!), Thalassemia.
    - Normocytic: Acute blood loss, Chronic disease.
    - Macrocytic: B12/Folate deficiency, Alcohol.
  • White Cell Count (WBC):
    - Neutrophilia: Bacterial infection, Tissue necrosis (Pancreatitis), Trauma (Surgery stress).
    - Lymphocytosis: Viral infection.
    - Leukopenia: Sepsis (Marrow suppression), Chemotherapy.
  • Platelets:
    - Thrombocytopenia: Sepsis, DIC (consumption), Liver disease (Hypersplenism). Risk of spontaneous bleed if <20.
biochemistry:
Urea & Electrolytes (U&E)

  • Creatinine: Specific for renal function.
  • Urea: Isolated Rise: Suggests Upper GI Bleed (digested blood protein) or Dehydration (Pre-renal).
  • Potassium (K+):
    - Hyperkalemia (>5.5): EMERGENCY (Arrhythmia/Arrest). Causes: Renal failure, Acidosis, Rhabdomyolysis, Suxamethonium. Rx: Calcium Gluconate (protect heart) + Insulin/Dextrose.
    - Hypokalemia (<3.5): Causes Ileus, muscle weakness.
liver_profile:
Liver Function Tests (LFTs)

  • Enzymes:
    - Hepatocellular: ALT/AST > ALP. (Hepatitis, Ischemia).
    - Cholestatic: ALP/GGT > ALT. (Gallstones, Cancer Head of Pancreas).
  • Synthetic Function:
    - Albumin: Long half-life (20d). Low in Chronic Liver Disease/Malnutrition.
    - INR/PT: Short half-life (Hours). Best marker for Acute Liver Failure.
inflammatory:
Acute Phase Reactants

  • CRP: Lags 24h behind clinical state. CRP >150 on Day 3-4 post-op is 80% predictive of Anastomotic Leak.
  • Amylase: >3x Upper Limit = Pancreatitis. Short half-life.
  • Lipase: More specific/sensitive for Pancreatitis.

name: Routine Imaging Studies
plain_xray:
Plain Radiography

  • Chest X-ray (Erect): Gold standard for Pneumoperitoneum (free air under diaphragm) in perforated viscus.
  • Abdominal X-ray (Supine): Diagnostic for Intestinal Obstruction (Dilated loops, Air-fluid levels).
    - Small Bowel: Central, >3cm, Valvulae Conniventes (cross full width).
    - Large Bowel: Peripheral, >6cm, Haustra (partial width).
    - Volvulus: Coffee bean sign (Sigmoid).
ultrasound:
Ultrasound (USG)

No radiation. High frequency sound.
Uses:
- Biliary: Stones (Acoustic shadow), Wall thickness >3mm (Cholecystitis).
- Renal: Hydronephrosis, Stones (if large).
- Vascular: DVT (Compression), Carotid stenosis.
- Trauma: FAST Scan (Free fluid in Morrison's pouch).
Limitations: Obesity, Bowel gas obscures view.
ct_scan:
Computed Tomography (CT)

X-ray slices. High radiation.
Phases:
- Non-contrast: Stones (Renal/Ureteric).
- Arterial: Bleeding, Aortic Dissection.
- Portal Venous: Liver metastases, Abscess, Appendicitis.
Risks: Contrast Nephropathy (Pre-hydrate!), Anaphylaxis.
mri_nuclear:
MRI & Nuclear Medicine

MRI: Best for soft tissue.
- MRCP: Biliary tree (Stones/Strictures).
- Pelvic MRI: Rectal cancer staging (Mesorectal fascia).
Nuclear:
- PET-CT: FDG uptake. Staging cancer/Metastasis.
- HIDA: Biliary function (Cystic duct obstruction).
- Bone Scan: Osteoblastic mets (Prostate).

name: Endoscopic Procedures
upper_gi:
OGDS (Gastroscopy)

Visualizes Esophagus, Stomach, D1/D2.
Diagnostic: Biopsy (Ulcer/Ca), CLO test (H. pylori).
Therapeutic: Variceal Banding, Adrenaline/Clips (Bleeding Ulcer), PEG feeding tube.

ERCP

Side-viewing scope for Biliary/Pancreatic ducts.
Therapeutic: Sphincterotomy, Stone extraction, Stenting.
Risk: Pancreatitis (5-10%), Cholangitis, Perforation.
lower_gi:
Colonoscopy

Entire colon + terminal ileum.
Uses: CRC Screening, Polypectomy, IBD.
Risk: Perforation (1:1000).

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

Rectum/Sigmoid only. Quick prep (Enema).
eus:
Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

US probe on scope tip.
Uses: T-Staging (depth) of Esophageal/Pancreatic Ca. FNA of mediastinal nodes.

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
definitions:
Key Concepts

Cleaning: Physical removal of soil/organic matter. Mandatory first step.
Disinfection: Reduces viable organisms. May not kill spores.
Sterilization: Destruction of ALL micro-organisms including Spores and Prions.
spalding:
Spalding's Classification

Critical (Sterile): Enters sterile tissue/vascular system (Instruments, Implants). Requires Sterilization (Autoclave).
Semi-Critical: Contacts mucous membranes/non-intact skin (Endoscopes). Requires High-Level Disinfection.
Non-Critical: Contacts intact skin (BP cuff). Requires Low-Level Disinfection.
methods:
Methods

Autoclave (Moist Heat): 121°C for 15mins. Best for metal.
Ethylene Oxide: Gas for heat-sensitive plastics.
Glutaraldehyde: Liquid for endoscopes.
skin_prep:
Chlorhexidine (Alcohol): Superior. Residual effect. Binds keratin.
Povidone Iodine: Inactivated by blood/serum.

name: Sutures & Drains
sutures:
Suture Materials

  • Absorbable:
    - Vicryl (Polyglactin): Braided. 2-4 weeks. (Subcut, Bowel).
    - Monocryl: Monofilament. (Subcuticular Skin).
    - PDS (Polydioxanone): Monofilament. Long lasting 6w+. (Fascia/Mass closure).
  • Non-Absorbable:
    - Prolene: Monofilament. Inert. (Vascular, Mesh).
    - Ethilon (Nylon): Skin (remove).
    - Silk: Braided. (Drains, Ligatures).
drains:
Drains

Open Passive: Corrugated (high infection risk).
Closed Active (Suction): JP/Redivac. Negative pressure. (Mastectomy, Thyroid).
Indications: Remove dead space, evacuate fluid (blood/bile), Sentinel (monitor leak).
needles:
Taper (Round): Soft tissue (Bowel, Muscle).
Cutting: Triangular tip. Tough tissue (Skin, Fascia).

name: Anatomy of the Stomach
structure:
Gross Anatomy

Parts: Cardia (T11), Fundus (Gas bubble), Body (Acid/Parietal cells), Antrum (Grinding/G-cells), Pylorus (Sphincter L1).
Relations: Anterior (Liver, Abdominal wall). Posterior 'Stomach Bed' (Pancreas, Spleen, L-Kidney, Transverse Mesocolon - separated by Lesser Sac).
blood_supply:
Arterial Supply (Celiac Trunk)

  • Lesser Curvature:
    - Left Gastric: Direct from Celiac.
    - Right Gastric: From Common Hepatic.
  • Greater Curvature:
    - Left Gastroepiploic: From Splenic.
    - Right Gastroepiploic: From GDA.
  • Fundus: Short Gastric Arteries (from Splenic). *Surgical Danger:* Avulsion during Splenectomy causes massive hemorrhage.
nerve_lymph:
Nerves & Lymph

Nerves: Vagus (CN X). Anterior (Left) & Posterior (Right) trunks. Nerve of Latarjet: Supplies antral pump - preserved in Highly Selective Vagotomy.
Lymph: Follows arteries.
- Virchow's Node: Left Supraclavicular (Troisier's sign). Spread via Thoracic Duct.
- Sister Mary Joseph Nodule: Umbilical met via Falciform ligament.

name: Anatomy of Alimentary Tract
large_bowel:
Colon Features

Distinguished by: Taeniae Coli (3 bands), Haustra (sacculations), Appendices Epiploicae (fat tags).
Blood Supply:
- SMA (Midgut): Cecum to Proximal 2/3 Transverse.
- IMA (Hindgut): Distal 1/3 Transverse to Rectum.
- Marginal Artery of Drummond: Anastomosis between SMA/IMA.
Watershed Areas: Griffith's Point (Splenic flexure) & Sudeck's Point (Rectosigmoid). Highest risk of Ischemic Colitis.
rectum_anal:
Rectum & Anal Canal

Rectum: No Taeniae. Peritoneum covers upper 1/3 only.
Anal Canal: 4cm.
- Dentate Line: Watershed. Above = Columnar/Visceral (Painless). Below = Squamous/Somatic (Painful).
- Sphincters: Internal (Involuntary/Autonomic), External (Voluntary/Pudendal N).
- Porto-Systemic Anastomosis: Superior Rectal V (Portal) <-> Inferior Rectal V (Systemic). Site of Varices.

name: Anatomy of Hepatobiliary System
liver:
Liver Anatomy

Couinaud Segments (I-VIII): Based on vascular inflow/outflow. Caudate Lobe (I): Independent drainage to IVC.
Blood Supply: 75% Portal Vein (Nutrient rich), 25% Hepatic Artery (O2 rich). Pringle Maneuver: Clamping hepatoduodenal ligament controls liver inflow (Portal v + Hepatic a).
biliary_calot:
Biliary Tree & Calot's

Common Hepatic Duct + Cystic Duct -> Common Bile Duct (CBD).
Calot's Triangle:
- Sup: Liver Edge.
- Med: Common Hepatic Duct.
- Lat: Cystic Duct.
Content: Cystic Artery (from Right Hepatic), Lund's Node.
Moynihan's Hump: Tortuous Right Hepatic Artery looping into triangle. Danger of ligation.

name: Breast & Axilla Anatomy
structure:
Structure & Supply

Modified sweat gland. Cooper's Ligaments: Attach skin to fascia (dimpling in cancer). Retromammary Space: Allows movement.
Arterial: Internal Thoracic (60%), Lateral Thoracic, Thoracoacromial.
Venous: Batson's Plexus: Valveless vertebral veins. Route for spinal metastases.
lymphatics:
Lymphatic Drainage

75% to Axillary Nodes. 25% to Internal Mammary.
Axillary Levels (Berg): Defined by Pectoralis Minor.
- I: Lateral. II: Posterior. III: Medial (Apical).
nerves:
Nerves at Risk

1. Long Thoracic (C5-7): Serratus Anterior. Injury -> Winged Scapula.
2. Thoracodorsal: Latissimus Dorsi. Injury -> Weak shoulder adduction.
3. Intercostobrachial: Sensory to inner arm. Injury -> Numbness.

name: Neck & Thyroid Anatomy
thyroid:
Thyroid Relations

Enclosed in Pretracheal Fascia (moves with swallow).
Arterial: Superior Thyroid (ECA), Inferior Thyroid (Thyrocervical trunk).
Venous: Sup/Mid -> IJV. Inf -> Brachiocephalic.
nerves:
Nerves at Risk

Recurrent Laryngeal (RLN): In tracheoesophageal groove. Injury -> Hoarseness (Unilateral) or Airway Obstruction (Bilateral).
External Laryngeal: With Sup Thyroid Artery. Injury -> Loss of high pitch voice (Cricothyroid).

name: Anatomy of Genitourinary System
kidney:
Kidneys

Retroperitoneal. T12-L3. Hilum (Ant->Post): Vein, Artery, Pelvis.
Supply: Renal Artery -> 5 End-Arteries (Segmental). No collateral circulation (Infarction risk).
ureter:
Ureters

Retroperitoneal. On Psoas Major.
Relations: Cross OVER Iliac Bifurcation. Pass UNDER Uterine Artery ('Water under bridge').
Constrictions: 1. PUJ. 2. Pelvic Brim. 3. VUJ (Narrowest).
referral:
Referred Pain

Kidney (T10-L1) -> Loin.
Ureter (T11-L2) -> Loin to Groin/Scrotum/Labia (Genitofemoral nerve).

name: Regions of the Abdomen
regions_9:
The 9 Regions

Divided by Mid-clavicular lines (vertical), Transpyloric plane (L1), and Transtubercular plane (L5).
  • Right Hypochondrium: Liver, GB.
  • Epigastrium: Stomach, Pancreas.
  • Left Hypochondrium: Spleen.
  • Flanks: Kidneys, Colon.
  • RIF: Appendix, Cecum.
  • LIF: Sigmoid.
planes:
Transpyloric Plane (L1)

Contains: Pylorus, Pancreas neck, SMA origin, Portal vein formation, Renal hila, Tip of 9th cartilage.

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
boundaries:
MALT Mnemonic

Muscle (Roof), Aponeurosis (Ant), Ligament (Floor), Transversalis (Post).
Contents: Spermatic Cord (Vas, Artery, Pampiniform plexus) + Ilioinguinal Nerve (On top of cord).
clinical:
Hernias

Deep Ring: Mid-inguinal point. Defect = Indirect Hernia.
Hesselbach's Triangle: Medial to Inf Epigastric vessels. Defect = Direct Hernia.

name: Femoral Triangle
contents:
NAVEL (Lat to Med)

Nerve (Femoral - Outside sheath), Artery, Vein, Empty space (Canal), Lymphatics.
Femoral Sheath: Contains A, V, Canal.
hernia:
Femoral Hernia

Through Femoral Canal. Below & Lateral to Pubic Tubercle. Medial border is Lacunar Ligament (Rigid). High strangulation risk.

name: Shock
definition:
Definition & Pathophysiology

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. Defined by perfusion (Lactate, Urine, Mental State), NOT just BP.
classification:
Types of Shock

  • Hypovolemic: Loss of circulating volume. (Hemorrhage, Burns, DKA).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, Cardiac Output (CO) ↓, SVR ↑ (Vasoconstriction - cold skin).
  • Cardiogenic: Pump failure. (MI, Arrhythmia, Valve rupture).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑ (JVP raised/Pulm Edema), CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Obstructive: Extracardiac physical blockage. (Tension Pneumothorax, Tamponade, Massive PE).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑, CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Distributive: Vasodilation / Relative Hypovolemia. (Sepsis, Anaphylaxis, Neurogenic).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, CO ↑ (Hyperdynamic early), SVR ↓↓↓ (Vasodilation - warm skin).
management:
Management Priorities

1. Hypovolemic: Stop bleeding! Volume Resuscitation (Warmed Crystalloids -> Blood Products 1:1:1). Inotropes are contraindicated in an empty heart.
2. Cardiogenic: Fluid restriction. Inotropes (Dobutamine). Revascularization (PCI).
3. Septic: Sepsis 6 Bundle. Fluids first (30ml/kg). Vasopressors (Noradrenaline) if fluid refractory. Antibiotics <1hr.
hemorrhage_classes:
ATLS Classification of Hemorrhage (70kg male)

  • Class I (<15% / <750ml): Vitals normal. Slight anxiety. (Blood donation).
  • Class II (15-30% / 750-1500ml): Tachycardia (>100), Narrow Pulse Pressure (Diastolic rises), Tachypnea. Urine normal.
  • Class III (30-40% / 1500-2000ml): Hypotension (Late sign!), Tachycardia (>120), Confusion, Urine <15ml/hr. Requires Blood Transfusion.
  • Class IV (>40% / >2000ml): Coma, Anuric, Severe Hypotension/Undetectable. Immediate Exsanguination threat.

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
1. Ebb Phase (0-24h)

'Shock phase'. Goal: Immediate survival.
Features: Hypometabolism, Decreased Cardiac Output, Decreased Temp, Vasoconstriction. Insulin drops.
Priority: Resuscitation (Stop bleeding, restore volume).

2. Flow Phase (Days-Weeks)

'Catabolic phase'. Goal: Repair.
Features: Hypermetabolism (High CO, High Temp).
- Catabolism: Muscle protein breakdown (Gluconeogenesis) -> Negative nitrogen balance.
- Insulin Resistance: 'Stress Diabetes' (High blood sugar provides fuel).
- Fluid Retention: ADH (Water) and Aldosterone (Na+).

3. Recovery Phase

Anabolic. Restoration of fat/protein stores. Diuresis.
mediators:
Neuro-Endocrine Response

Afferent Nerves: Pain stimuli trigger Hypothalamus.
Hormones:
- Catabolic (Counter-regulatory): Cortisol, Glucagon, Adrenaline, Growth Hormone. (Drive glucose up).
- Anabolic: Insulin (But resistance prevents its action).
Cytokines: IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha (Cause fever, anorexia, acute phase proteins like CRP).
optimization:
Attenuating the Response

1. Analgesia: Blocks afferent neural stimuli.
2. Early Nutrition: Prevents catabolism.
3. Temp Control: Prevents coagulopathy.

name: Chemotherapy Principles
intent:
Classification

Neoadjuvant: Before surgery. To downstage (shrink) tumor.
Adjuvant: After surgery. To treat micrometastases/prevent recurrence.
Palliative: Symptom control only.
agents:
Agents

Antimetabolites: 5-FU (GI).
Platinum: Cisplatin (DNA cross-linker).
Taxanes: Docetaxel (Breast).
Side Effects: Nausea, Alopecia, Neuropathy.
toxicity:
Neutropenic Sepsis

Definition: Temp >38°C + Neutrophils <0.5.
Action: Medical Emergency! Resuscitate + IV Broad Spectrum Abx (Tazocin) within 1 hour.

name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
etiology:
Etiology & Pathogenesis

Caused by Entamoeba histolytica protozoa. Transmission via fecal-oral route (cysts). Trophozoites invade colon (flask-shaped ulcers) -> Portal vein -> Liver (Liquefactive necrosis). Common in tropical regions / alcoholics.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Presentation: RUQ pain (may refer to right shoulder), High swinging fever, Rigors, Night sweats, Weight loss.
Signs: Tender hepatomegaly, Intercostal tenderness. Jaundice is rare (only if huge).
Complication: Rupture into pleura (empyema), pericardium (tamponade), or peritoneum.
management:
Management

Investigation: USG (Hypoechoic, ill-defined), Serology (Amoebic Ab >95% sensitive). Aspiration yields 'Anchovy Sauce' pus (Sterile, odorless, necrotic hepatocytes).
Treatment: Metronidazole 800mg TDS for 10 days (Cures >90%). Follow with Diloxanide Furoate (luminal agent) to clear gut cysts. Aspiration only if: Large (>10cm), Left Lobe (Pericardial risk), or Failure of medical therapy.

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
etiology:
Etiology

Benign (Pyloric Stenosis): Chronic Peptic Ulcer Disease (Scarring/Fibrosis), Adult Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis.
Malignant: Antral Gastric Cancer, Pancreatic Head Cancer invading duodenum, Lymphoma.
metabolic_derangement:
Metabolic Derangement

Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis: Vomiting Gastric Acid (HCl) -> Loss of H+ and Cl- -> Alkalosis.
Paradoxical Aciduria: Dehydration leads to Aldosterone release to save Na+. Kidney initially exchanges Na+ for K+ (Hypokalemia). When K+ depleted, it exchanges Na+ for H+. Thus, acid (H+) is excreted in urine despite alkalotic blood.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Presentation: Projectile vomiting of undigested food (non-bilious), Weight loss, Early satiety.
Signs: Dehydration, Visible Peristalsis (L to R), Succussion Splash (sloshing sound on shaking abdomen >4h post-meal).
management:
Management

1. Resuscitation: Wide bore NG Tube (Lavage/Decompression). IV Fluids (0.9% Saline + K+). Avoid Hartmann's (Lactate -> Bicarb -> Worsens alkalosis).
2. Diagnosis: OGDS (Biopsy).
3. Definitive: Balloon Dilation (Benign) or Stent/Gastrojejunostomy (Malignant).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
etiology:
Etiology

Cryptoglandular Theory (90%): Infection of intersphincteric anal glands -> Abscess -> Bursts into anal canal and skin -> Fistula tract.
Secondary Causes: Crohn's Disease (Multiple/Complex), TB, Malignancy, Radiation.
classification:
Parks Classification

1. Intersphincteric (45%): Most common. Tract confined between sphincters.
2. Trans-sphincteric (30%): Crosses external sphincter.
3. Suprasphincteric: Loops over Puborectalis.
4. Extrasphincteric: From rectum to skin (bypass sphincters).
clinical_features:
Goodsall's Rule

Predicts track path.
Anterior Opening: Radial straight track to dentate line.
Posterior Opening: Curved track to posterior midline (6 o'clock).
Exception: Anterior openings >3cm from anal verge track posteriorly.
management:
Management

Investigation: MRI Pelvis (Gold standard) or EUA.
Low Fistula (Not involving much sphincter): Fistulotomy (Lay open).
High Fistula: Sphincter-preserving. Seton (thread to drain/cut slowly), LIFT procedure, or Flap.

name: Diverticular Disease
pathology:
Pathophysiology

Acquired herniation of mucosa/submucosa through muscularis propria at weak points where vasa recta penetrate. Sigmoid Colon is most affected (Law of Laplace: High pressure, narrow lumen). Rectum is spared (complete muscle coat). Risk: Low fiber diet.
complications:
Complications

1. Diverticulitis: Inflammation/Micro-perforation. LIF pain, fever ('Left sided appendicitis').
2. Perforation: Fecal peritonitis (Hinchey IV). Surgical emergency.
3. Bleeding: Erosion of vasa recta. Major cause of massive painless lower GI bleed.
4. Fistula: Colovesical (Pneumaturia/UTIs) or Colovaginal.
management:
Management

Uncomplicated: Antibiotics, liquid diet.
Abscess (Hinchey II): CT-guided percutaneous drainage.
Perforation (Hinchey III/IV): Hartmann's Procedure (Resection of sigmoid + End Colostomy).
Bleeding: Resuscitation (most stop). Angio-embolization/Surgery if persistent.

name: Hemorrhoids
anatomy:
Anal Cushions

Normal vascular cushions (sinusoids) at 3, 7, and 11 o'clock.
Internal: Origin above dentate line. Visceral sensation (Painless). Covered by mucosa.
External: Origin below dentate line. Somatic sensation (Painful if thrombosed). Covered by skin.
clinical_features:
Presentation

Bleeding: Bright red, splash in the pan, separate from stool.
Prolapse Grading:
I: Bleed only, no prolapse.
II: Prolapse but spontaneous reduction.
III: Prolapse requiring manual reduction.
IV: Irreducible prolapse.
Pain: UNUSUAL for internal piles unless thrombosed/strangulated.
management:
Management

Conservative: Fiber, fluids, laxatives.
Office Procedures (Grade I/II): Rubber Band Ligation (Gold standard - causes necrosis/sloughing), Sclerotherapy.
Surgical (Grade III/IV): Hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan) or Stapled Hemorrhoidopexy (PPH).

name: Skin Malignancies
bcc:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

Most common. Arises from basal layer. UV exposure.
Features: Pearly nodule, rolled edge, telangiectasia, central ulcer ('Rodent Ulcer').
Behavior: Locally invasive (can destroy bone/cartilage) but Metastasis is extremely rare.
Rx: Excision (3-4mm margin), Mohs surgery (face), Radiotherapy.
scc:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Arises from keratinocytes. Precursor: Actinic Keratosis / Bowen's.
Features: Everted edge, keratin pearl, ulcerated.
Marjolin's Ulcer: SCC arising in chronic wound/burn scar/sinus. Aggressive.
Behavior: Metastasizes to regional lymph nodes.
Rx: Wide excision (1cm margin), Node clearance if palpable.
melanoma:
Malignant Melanoma

Arises from melanocytes.
ABCDE: Asymmetry, Border irregular, Color variation, Diameter >6mm, Evolution.
Prognosis: Depends on Breslow Thickness (depth).
Rx: Wide excision (margin depends on depth) + Sentinel Node Biopsy.

name: Flail Chest
pathophysiology:
Pathophysiology

Fracture of 3 or more consecutive ribs in 2 or more places. Creates a floating segment.
Paradoxical Respiration: Segment moves IN on inspiration, OUT on expiration.
Hypoxia Mechanism: NOT just mechanics. Primary cause is the underlying Pulmonary Contusion (bruised lung -> shunting/edema) and Pain (splinting -> atelectasis).
management:
Management Priorities

1. Analgesia: Epidural, Paravertebral Block, or PCA is critical to allow coughing/breathing.
2. Oxygen/CPAP: Positive pressure splints the chest internally.
3. Intubation: Indicated for respiratory failure (Hypoxia/Hypercapnia) despite analgesia.

name: Intussusception
etiology:
Etiology

Telescoping of proximal bowel (intussusceptum) into distal (intussuscipiens). Usually Ileum into Cecum.
Children (3m-3y): Idiopathic (90%). Peyer's patch hyperplasia (post-viral) acts as lead point.
Adults: Pathological lead point (Polyp, Tumor, Meckel's) is present in 90%.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Triad:
1. Intermittent colicky pain (infant screams/draws legs up, pallor).
2. 'Redcurrant jelly' stool (late sign - mucosal ischemia/blood/mucus).
3. Palpable sausage-shaped mass (RUQ) + Empty RIF (Sign of Dance).
management:
Management

Investigation: USG ('Target' or 'Doughnut' sign).
Treatment:
- Radiological: Air or Barium Enema reduction. Diagnostic and Therapeutic. Success >80%. Contraindicated if peritonitis/shock.
- Surgical: If enema fails, peritonitis, or pathological lead point. Manual reduction or resection.

name: Varicocele
anatomy:
Pathology & Anatomy

Dilatation of pampiniform venous plexus. 90% Left sided.
Why Left? Left Testicular vein drains vertically into Renal Vein (high pressure) at right angle. Right drains obliquely into IVC. Also compressed by SMA ('Nutcracker phenomenon').
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Signs: 'Bag of worms' feel. Cough impulse. Disappears on lying down (if it doesn't -> Retroperitoneal mass).
Grading:
I: Palpable only with Valsalva.
II: Palpable without Valsalva.
III: Visible through skin.
Red Flag: Sudden onset Left varicocele or ANY Right varicocele suggests Renal Cell Carcinoma (tumor thrombus in renal vein).
management:
Management

Indications for Rx: Pain, Infertility (raised scrotal temp affects spermatogenesis), Testicular atrophy (in adolescents), Cosmetic.
Options: Conservative (Scrotal support), Embolization (Radiological), Surgical Ligation (Open/Laparoscopic).

name: Hydronephrosis
etiology:
Etiology

Dilation of renal pelvis/calyces due to obstruction.
Unilateral: Stone (Ureteric), Stricture, TCC Ureter, Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO), Extrinsic compression.
Bilateral: Bladder Outflow Obstruction (BPH, Ca Prostate), Urethral Stricture, Retroperitoneal Fibrosis.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Acute: Renal Colic (Loin to groin pain).
Chronic: Dull ache or Asymptomatic.
Dietl's Crisis: Intermittent severe flank pain/nausea after drinking large fluids (seen in PUJO).
Anuria: Only if complete bilateral obstruction or solitary kidney.
management:
Management

Investigation: USG (Grade dilation), CT KUB (Stones), MAG3 Renogram (Differentiates functional obstruction from non-obstructive dilation).
Treatment: Relieve obstruction to save kidney.
- Upper: JJ Stent or PCN (Nephrostomy).
- Lower: Catheter (Urethral/Suprapubic).

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
definition_features:
Definitions

Keloid: An overgrowth of dense fibrous tissue (Type I & III collagen) that extends BEYOND the boundaries of the original wound. It does not regress spontaneously.
Hypertrophic Scar: Excessive scar tissue that remains confined WITHIN the boundaries of the original wound. It often regresses with time (6-12 months).
epidemiology_risk:
Risk Factors

Keloid:
- Race: Darker skin types (African/Asian).
- Genetics: Familial predisposition.
- Sites: Sternum, Deltoid, Earlobes, Upper Back (High tension areas rare).
Hypertrophic:
- Tension: Wounds closed under tension or crossing Langer's lines.
- Infection: Delayed healing.
- Burns: Deep dermal burns.
pathology_comparison:
Pathology Differences

FeatureKeloidHypertrophic
ExtentInvades normal skinConfined to wound
RegressionRareCommon
OnsetDelayed (>3 months)Early (<4 weeks)
CollagenThick, disorganized bundlesFine, organized parallel fibers
RecurrenceHigh (>50% post-excision)Low
management_treatment:
Management

Prevention: Minimize tension, avoid mid-sternal incisions in high-risk patients.
Keloid Treatment:
1. Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone): First line. Softens and flattens.
2. Pressure Garments: Continuous pressure (e.g., ear clips).
3. Silicone Gel Sheets.
4. Surgery: NEVER excise alone (recurrence is larger). Must combine with post-op Radiotherapy or Steroids.
Hypertrophic Treatment: Massage, Silicone, Time (wait 1 year before revision).
